title: Southern Cross 28
text:
The Southern Cross 28, also called the Gillmer 28, is an American <a href="sailboat">sailboat</a> that was designed by <a href="Thomas%20C.%20Gillmer">Thomas C. Gillmer</a> and first built in 1978.
Production.
The design was built by <a href="C.%20E.%20Ryder">C. E. Ryder</a> in <a href="Bristol%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Bristol, Rhode Island</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, but it is now out of production.
Design.
The Southern Cross 28 is a recreational <a href="keelboat">keelboat</a>, built predominantly of <a href="fiberglass">fiberglass</a>, with <a href="teak">teak</a> wood trim. The deck is fiberglass with a <a href="balsa">balsa</a> core, while the hull is fiberglass with an Airtex foam core.
The design has a <a href="cutter%20rig">cutter</a> <a href="sloop">sloop</a> rig, with a boom-mounted, self-tending <a href="staysail">staysail</a>, a teak <a href="bowsprit">bowsprit</a>, a spooned <a href="raked%20stem">raked stem</a>, a raised <a href="Transom%20%28nautical%29">transom</a>, a <a href="skeg">skeg</a>-mounted <a href="rudder">rudder</a> controlled by a <a href="tiller">tiller</a> and a fixed swept fin <a href="keel">keel</a>. The keel design is a modified long keel, with a cutout for the propeller shaft, creating a fin keel. It displaces and carries of lead ballast.
The boat has a draft of with the standard keel fitted.
The boat is fitted with a <a href="Universal%20Atomic%204">Universal Atomic 4</a> <a href="gasoline%20engine">gasoline engine</a> for docking and maneuvering. The fuel tank holds and the fresh water tank has a capacity of .
The <a href="Galley%20%28kitchen%29">galley</a> is mounted on the port side at the bottom of the companionway stairs, with a sink and two-burner, alcohol-fired stove. The <a href="icebox">icebox</a> is mounted to starboard and serves as a navigation table as well. The <a href="Head%20%28watercraft%29">head</a> is forward, just behind the bow "V"-berth and includes storage space and a hanging locker. It has privacy doors. Additional sleeping accommodation in the main cabin includes a port settee that extends under the head and a starboard settee that opens to a double. The interior wooden trim is all teak.
Ventilation is provided by <a href="dorade%20vents">dorade vents</a>, three cowl vents, a forward hatch and six opening portlights. A midship opening hatch was a factory option.
The boat came factory-equipped with two <a href="halyard">halyard</a> winches and two <a href="genoa%20%28sail%29">genoa</a> winches. A <a href="topping%20lift">topping lift</a> and <a href="jiffy%20reefing">jiffy reefing</a> were standard. Optional factory equipment included <a href="roller%20furling">roller furling</a>, a <a href="boom%20vang">boom vang</a>, <a href="spinnaker">spinnaker</a> and tracks for the genoa.
The design has a <a href="Performance%20Handicap%20Racing%20Fleet">PHRF</a> racing average handicap of 230.
Operational history.
Sailor Donna Lange completed two solo global <a href="circumnavigation">circumnavigation</a>s on board her Southern Cross 28, named "Inspired Insanity". Her 2005 voyage lasted 17 months and she repeated the trip in 2015. During the latter voyage the boat experienced a <a href="Capsizing">knockdown</a> and <a href="dismasting">dismasting</a> in winds. As a result, Lange took the boat though the <a href="Panama%20Canal">Panama Canal</a> instead of rounding <a href="Cape%20Horn">Cape Horn</a>.
In a review of the design, Richard Sherwood wrote, "the keel is modified full, and the rudder skeg is substantial. Forward, the hull flares. Displacement is moderate. With a self-tending staysail, single-handing is simple. As with all cutters, the amount of sail carried can be varied significantly. As the manufacturer says, the Southern Cross 'looks like a sailboat.'"
In a 2018 review, "Sailing" magazine writer David Liscio described the design as, "a diminutive sturdy cruiser that is capable of mighty bluewater passages".
